bestBHT.bht: Let us be cautious not to judge one another so that we do not incur the guilt of destroying each other. This emphasize the need for self-reflection and highlights the remarkable testimony to the absolute divinity of Christ. As we approach the day of judgment, every work and purpose will be examined by God's unerring justice. Only God, being omniscient, is qualified to conduct the general judgment, emphasizing the importance of not condemning our brethren. Each person will have to give an account of themselves to God, and all will ultimately be subject to the judgment of Christ.

Henry Alford: Seeing that our account to God will be of each man’s own self, let us take heed lest by judging one another we incur the guilt of destroying one another.
The stress is on concerning himself: and the next verse refers back to it, laying the emphasis on one another.
Judging here in the general sense of ‘pass judgment on,’ including both the despising of the strong and the judging of the weak.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Now, if it be remembered that all this is adduced quite incidentally, to show that CHRIST is the absolute Master of all Christians, to rule their judgments and feelings towards each other while 'living,' and to dispose of them 'dying,' the testimony which it bears to the absolute Divinity of Christ will appear remarkable.
On any other view, the quotation to show that we shall all stand before the judgment-seat of God would be a strange proof that Christians are all amenable to Christ.
The testimony which it bears to the absolute Divinity of Christ will appear remarkable.
Albert Barnes: In the fearful arraignment of that day every work and purpose shall be brought forth, and tried by the unerring standard of justice.

As we shall be called to so fearful an account with God, we should not be engaged in condemning our brethren, but should examine whether we are prepared to give up our account with joy, and not with grief.

No being that is not 'omniscient' can be qualified to judge the secrets of all people. None who has not 'seen' human purposes at all times, and in all places; who has not been a witness of the conduct by day and by night; who has not been present with all the race at all times, and who in the great day cannot discern the true character of the soul, can be qualified to conduct the general judgment. Yet none can possess these qualifications but God.
John Calvin: This conclusion invites us to humility and lowliness of mind: and hence he immediately draws this inference, — that we are not to judge one another
He indeed indirectly reproves those malignant censors, who employ all their acuteness in finding out something faulty in the life of their brethren
Thus we see that forbearance is enjoined on both parties
Philip Schaff: The emphasis rests on ‘each one of us,’ not on ‘of himself,’ or, ‘to God.’ There is no exception."
Let each remember this, and each will be guarded against judging his brother.
‘That which precedes means: 'Do not judge thy brother, since God will judge him;' this verse means: 'Judge thou thyself, since God will judge thee.'
Archibald T. Robertson: Shall give account (λογον δωσε). So Aleph A C rather than αποδωσε of Textus Receptus. Common use of λογος for account (bookkeeping, ledger) as in Luke 16:2.
John Gill: from whence it necessarily follows, that every man, and so every Christian, strong or weak, whatever may be his gifts, talents, and abilities, shall give an account of himself to God
which is another proof of his deity, for he will be the Judge
however, this is certain, that the saints will have upon this reckoning, in what sort soever it may be, a full and open discharge, through the blood and righteousness of Christ

bhtAttempts.bht: In Romans 14:12, the emphasis is on each person giving an account to God, highlighting the importance of self-examination rather than judging one another. The verse serves as a remarkable testimony to the absolute divinity of Christ, underscoring His role as the ultimate ruler of Christians both in life and in death. As we approach the fearful day of judgment, every work and purpose will be brought forth and tried by the unerring standard of justice. Only God, being omniscient, can truly judge the secrets of all people. Therefore, it is not our place to condemn others but to judge ourselves and ensure that we are ready to give up our account with joy. This conclusion calls us to humility and forbearance, reminding both the strong and the weak that they will each be held accountable to God. Regardless of our gifts, talents, or abilities, every Christian will ultimately be subject to the judgment of Christ, though the saints can take comfort in their full and open discharge through the blood and righteousness of Christ.

In considering our individual accounts before God, it is crucial that we refrain from judging one another, lest we destroy one another. The verse underscores the divinity of Christ, revealing His authority to rule over the judgments and feelings of believers. On the day of judgment, every work and purpose will be examined by God's perfect justice. As we prepare for this fearful reckoning, we should refrain from condemning our brethren and instead focus on our own readiness to stand before God. Ultimately, each Christian will face the judgment of Christ, but the blood and righteousness of Christ provide a secure discharge for the saints.
